awd_titl_txt: CRII:OAC: Machine Learning- Enhanced Multiscale Simulation of Fiber Composites
awd_abstract_narration:
Many engineered materials such as fiber composites have a hierarchical structure that spans multiple length scales. The analysis and design of these materials rely on multiscale simulations whose computational costs significantly increase if the structure is large and if the material deformation depends on its loading history. These high costs prohibit computationally intensive studies such as uncertainty propagation and design optimization. To tackle this challenge, the project employs recent advances in high performance computing and machine learning to accelerate multiscale simulations by orders of magnitude without compromising accuracy. The developed methods and tools are applicable to many materials systems and the testbed on fiber composites benefits a wide range of academic and industrial efforts since these materials are heavily used in, for example, the automobile and aerospace industries.

This work develops cyberinfrastructure foundations that will enable acceleration of multiscale simulations while (1) minimizing the information loss incurred in inter-scale communication, and (2) considering various uncertainty sources such as spatial variation of microstructural properties and morphologies. The project builds mechanistic machine learning (ML) models that emulate complex and history-dependent microstructural deformations that embody a broad range of nanoscale and mesoscale effects to ensure transferability. The ML models are integrated with a message passing interface (MPI) design that leverages the hierarchical nature of the multiscale simulation to achieve two-level parallelism, both within and across the computational nodes of a compute cluster. The message passing is employed to manage inter-scale and intra-scale data transfer during multiscale simulation of a light-weight fiber composite whose microstructures spatially vary due to manufacturing uncertainties. The simulations on composite materials aim to increase understanding of how their properties are affected by inter- and intra- microstructural uncertainties, constituent properties, deformation history, and microstructure morphology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Many engineered materials such as fiber composites have a hierarchical structure that spans multiple length-scales. The analysis and design of these materials rely on multiscale simulations whose computational costs significantly increase if material deformation is size- and history-dependent (e.g., plastic deformation). These high costs prohibit compute-intensive studies such as uncertainty propagation and inverse design. To tackle this challenge, this project built mechanistic machine learning (ML) models that learn history-dependent microstructural deformations at small length-scales. The learning task was achieved by developing algorithms, portable software packages, and an end-to-end training pipeline on distributed memory machines. Integration of these ML models with spatial random processes and using the resulting combination in multiscale simulations not only provides orders of magnitudes speedups, but also enables propagation of spatially varying microstructural uncertainties from fine scales to the coarse scale. 

Intellectual Merit: This work developed the cyberinfrastructure (CI) foundations that enable drastic acceleration of multiscale simulations while (1) minimizing the information loss incurred in inter-scale communications, and (2) considering various uncertainty sources such as spatial variation of microstructural properties and morphologies. The CI foundations are built in two interconnected research tasks and include a testbed on predictive modeling of heterogeneous fiber composites. Task A built mechanistic ML models that emulate complex and history-dependent microstructural deformations. The training data required for building these ML models are generated by high-fidelity finite element (FE) simulations and embody a broad range of nanoscale and mesoscale effects to ensure transferability to other application. Task B developed a message passing interface (MPI) that leverages the hierarchical nature of the multiscale simulation to achieve two-level parallelism. This MPI integrates the ML models with manufacturing-informed spatial random processes to simulate the deformation of a stochastic multiscale structure.

The developed CI was applied to composites to obtain a fundamental understanding on how their properties are affected by inter and intra microstructural uncertainties, constituent properties, deformation history, and microstructure morphology. This work advances the state-of-the-art in multiscale materials simulations by (1) reducing computational costs, (2) considering manufacturing-induced uncertainty sources, (3) decreasing the information loss incurred when bridging the length-scales, and (4) providing 3D predictions at multiple length-scales that can be compared against (or calibrated via) corresponding experimental data.

Broader Impacts: The pace of discovery and design of hierarchical materials, especially in the presence of uncertainty, is hampered by the high computational costs of multiscale simulations. By using the recent technological advances in deep learning and computing, the outcomes of this project has the potential to address this limitation within a data-driven approach. The outcomes of this project are disseminated via publications and open source codes. 

 


Last Modified: 11/11/2024
Modified by: Ramin Bostanabad
